Lesson(Text Version).title: Basic Vietnamese Vocabulary
Lesson(Text Version).shortDescription: This lesson goes over essential Vietnamese words for simple sentences.
Lesson(Text Version).description:
Vietnamese is a tonal language spoken primarily in Vietnam. In this first lesson, you’ll learn some essential words that will help you form simple sentences. The word for "I" or "me" is tôi , and it's commonly used in everyday speech. To say "am," you use là when stating identity or describing something (e.g., “I am…”). The word "trong" means "in" and is often used to describe location. To say "Vietnamese," say tiếng Việt. These basic words are crucial for building sentences like “I am Vietnamese,” which translates to “Tôi là người Việt Nam.”
Now let’s practice putting these words together. For example, if you want to say “He is Vietnamese,” you would say “Anh ấy là người Việt Nam.” Similarly, to say “She is Vietnamese,” you’d use “Cô ấy là người Việt Nam.” As you can see, the structure is quite logical and easy to follow once you understand the meaning of each word. This foundation will allow you to create many other sentences using similar patterns. You can also substitute “người Việt Nam” with other nationalities to express different identities, such as “người Mỹ” for American or “người Anh” for British.
trivia: Did you know that "tôi" can mean both “I” and “me” in Vietnamese?
Did you know that Vietnamese has no gendered pronouns like “he” or “she” unless you're being specific?
Did you know that “tiếng” literally means “sound” but becomes “language” when combined with a country name?

Lesson(Text Version).title: Greetings and Introductions
Lesson(Text Version).shortDescription: This lesson teaches how to greet people and introduce yourself in Vietnamese.
Lesson(Text Version).description:
In this lesson, you'll learn how to greet people and introduce yourself in Vietnamese. A common greeting is “Xin chào” , which means “Hello.” To ask someone’s name, you can say “Bạn tên gì?” which translates to “What is your name?” If you're introducing yourself, you might say “Tôi tên là [your name]” , meaning “My name is…”
You can make greetings more formal by using titles like “Anh” (for an older male), “Chị” (for an older female), or “Cô” (for a woman who is much older or in a position of respect). For example, “Chào chị!” means “Hello, older sister!” or “Chào cô!” means “Hello, ma’am!” These distinctions are important in Vietnamese culture, where showing respect through language is valued.
When meeting someone new, it’s polite to smile and greet them warmly. You can add phrases like “Rất vui được gặp bạn” which means “Nice to meet you.” When ending a conversation, “Tạm biệt” means “Goodbye.” Learning these expressions will help you connect with native speakers and show cultural awareness. You can also adjust your tone depending on whether you're speaking to a friend, teacher, or elder.
trivia: Did you know that Vietnamese use different forms of address based on age and gender to show respect?
Did you know that “Chào” alone can also mean “hi” or “hello” in informal settings?
Did you know that Vietnamese greetings often include body language like smiles and small bows?

Lesson(Text Version).title: Verb Conjugation Basics
Lesson(Text Version).shortDescription: This lesson explains how verbs work in Vietnamese, focusing on their unchanging forms.
Lesson(Text Version).description:
In Vietnamese, verbs don’t change form based on who is doing the action. Unlike Spanish, Vietnamese doesn't conjugate verbs for subject pronouns. For example, the verb “ăn” means both "to eat" and "eats." So you can say “Tôi ăn cơm” (I eat rice), “Bạn ăn cơm” (You eat rice), and “Họ ăn cơm” (They eat rice), all using the same verb form.
This makes Vietnamese grammar simpler in some ways. However, time indicators are added to show tense. For example, “Tôi ăn cơm hôm qua” means “I ate rice yesterday,” while “Tôi sẽ ăn cơm tối nay” means “I will eat rice tonight.” Also, adverbs like đang (currently) or sẽ (will) help indicate tense without changing the verb itself. This system may feel different if you're used to conjugated verbs in languages like Spanish or French, but it actually simplifies sentence construction.
Because there’s no conjugation, learning new verbs becomes easier, you only need to memorize one form per verb. Once you know the base verb, you can use it with any subject or time frame by simply adding the appropriate adverb or time expression. This makes Vietnamese very consistent and predictable compared to many other languages.
trivia: Did you know that Vietnamese verbs never change form, no matter who is doing the action?
Did you know that instead of conjugating verbs, Vietnamese adds time markers like hôm qua (yesterday) or mai (tomorrow)?
Did you know that the same verb can be used for “eat,” “eats,” and “eating” in Vietnamese?

Lesson(Text Version).title: Common Nouns and Food Vocabulary
Lesson(Text Version).shortDescription: This lesson covers essential nouns and food-related words in Vietnamese.
Lesson(Text Version).lessonTitle: Lesson 4: Common Nouns and Food Vocabulary
Lesson(Text Version).description:
In this lesson, we’ll learn some everyday nouns and food-related vocabulary. Knowing how to talk about what you eat is essential for daily conversations. Here are some key terms: nước means water, sữa means milk, táo means apple, hamburger is still hamburger , and bánh mì means sandwich. You can combine these words with verbs like ăn (to eat) and uống (to drink).
For example, to say “I drink water,” you’d say “Tôi uống nước.” To say “I eat apples,” you'd say “Tôi ăn táo.” And to translate “He eats hamburgers,” you'd say “Anh ấy ăn hamburger.” These structures mirror the ones we learned earlier, so they should feel familiar. Now, try practicing by creating your own sentences!
There are also many traditional Vietnamese dishes that you can describe using these words. For instance, phở is a popular noodle soup, and bún chả refers to grilled pork with noodles. By combining food items with verbs and subjects, you can build full descriptions of meals or preferences. Try saying “I like pho” – “Tôi thích phở.” This flexibility allows you to talk about food confidently even at the beginner level.
trivia: Did you know that bánh mì is considered one of the best street foods in the world?
Did you know that phở is pronounced like “fuh,” not like the letter F-O?
Did you know that Vietnamese borrowed many food words directly from French, like bánh mì ?

Lesson(Text Version).title: Verbs and Daily Actions
Lesson(Text Version).shortDescription: This lesson explores useful verbs for daily activities and household actions in Vietnamese.
Lesson(Text Version).description:
Let’s explore more useful verbs related to daily activities. Rửa means to wash, lau means to clean, xem means to watch or look at, and mở means to open. These verbs are used frequently in daily life and can be combined with objects like cửa (door), chén (dish), and phim (movie). For example, “Tôi rửa chén” means “I wash dishes.”
You can also build sentences like “Tôi mở cửa” (I open the door) or “Anh ấy lau nhà” (He cleans the house). Remember, Vietnamese verbs remain the same regardless of the subject. Just add the correct object and subject to complete the sentence. Let’s practice forming sentences using these verbs!
Using these verbs, you can describe your routine or chores around the house. For example, “Tôi xem phim vào buổi tối” means “I watch movies in the evening,” and “Cô ấy mở cửa sổ” means “She opens the window.” Understanding how to pair verbs with objects will greatly improve your ability to communicate clearly in Vietnamese.
trivia: Did you know that “rửa mặt” means “wash face” and is part of most people’s morning routines?
Did you know that “xem ti vi” is the common way to say “watch TV” in Vietnamese?
Did you know that “mở mắt” literally means “open eyes” and is used to describe waking up?
